subject: Re: JUnit 4 and public classes
msgSnippet: Elliotte ... My first workaround for this problem is to: - make the private method public (or package, or protected), BUT - annotate it with @TestPrivateShared
messageBody:
Elliotte
> Mostly it just offends my sense of programming aesthetics to have all
> these public classes and interfaces that aren't really part of the
> published interfaces.


My first workaround for this problem is to:
- make the private method public (or package, or protected),
BUT
- annotate it with @TestPrivateShared - *1 -
- use an IDEA editor inspections pair - *1- to enforce the new constraint.

(*1: that I created)

A first inspection highlights/tags as error any attempt to use a @TestOnly field/method/
class by production code that is not in the same class (== enforce the private aspect)

A second inspection finds in the code all the fields/methods/classes that could be private,
if it were not for tests, and tag them with @TestPrivateShared.

One could easily go one step further an use this information to remove the
@TestSharePrivate public members from the java doc.





My second workaround is to add a public method to the tested class, that is only to be
used by test code.
Example:
private Bar foo (){
...
}

@TestOnly
public Bar fooTestHook (){
return foo();
}


To make sure that no production code uses 'fooTestHook', I use another pair of editor
inspections.
Note: @TestOnly can decorate a field, method or even entire class.


Alain Ravet
